title: Remove yasuo's double crit passive.
body: He already has a passive that gives him a shield, so why should he have double crit? I feel like the double crit is just a stat increase with no gameplay. He simply doesn't need double crit. To compensate, increase his q base damage by 10.

replies.body:
>* remove 25% of a champion's DPS
>* compensate by adding 10 base damage to his empowered auto

Yes, this definitely an idea based on a solid grasp of the intricacies of the game.

That is the best joke I've heard in a bit. Remove his passive and replace it with what? Increasing his Q base damage by ten? That would barely even affect him. You know his Q base damage only goes up to 100 at max right? 10 more damage isn't going to replace what makes him strong. To compensate his crits do 10% less damage, not very high and I believe it should be 5% or 10% more but still.

The 10% reduction is actually pretty significant, because it's a multiplicative damage reduction rather than just -10% to his Crit Damage. His basic crits are 180% (150% on Qs), and his IE crits are 225% (187.5% on Qs). If it was reduced by 15/20%, he'd be sitting at 170/160% and 212.5/200% Crit Damage That's...really weak. Like, that would probably kill his mid-game spike and make him Lee Sin levels of terrible late-game.
people saying lee sin has a bad lategame always reminds me of the fact that the majority of league players are stuck in silver. makes sense i guess.

People who use rank instead of facts as an argument tend to have nothing of value to add to a conversation. Makes some sense, though, as they'd be far too busy measuring their dick and grinding to care about how a debate works.

i can tell you how a debate works:
one person states a thesis and backs it up with an argument, the other person states states his argument. very simple right?

well, then why do you not back your thesis "lee sin has a weak lategame" up with an argument? i dont feel inclined to argue with silver kids.

you say lee sin has no lategame. i say you are silver for a reason. both of these assertions have no foothold without reason behind them but if you wanna turn this "diamondplayer knows more than silverplayer by default" thing into a discussion, go ahead and explain lee sins weak lategame.

Lee Sin's late game falls off severely, even compared to most other bruisers, due to how it's scaled. He has better innate offense than defense, but both his offense and defense rely heavily on scaling for effectiveness. This leads to the catch-22 of either not building enough defense to survive in a fight *or* lacking the offensive power to be much of a threat for any reason other than kicking someone into his team. The only teams against which either situation plays into Lee's favor is when the enemy team--each player individually, as well as the group--is worse than the Lee and his team.

Put shortly, Lee Sin's effectiveness late game is reliant on his opponents picking poorly and being bad at the game. You can make as many flashy plays as you want, but in the end, if the team knows how Lee Sin works, they're not going to let him be more than an annoyance.
---
And yes, there's a reason I'm silver. Because I've played barely more than 50 ranked games in 6 years. As opposed to 3k+ games on just Summoner's Rift, at least a thousand more in the various other modes combined...**It's because I play Ranked less than 1% of the time.**

I have no real compulsion to consistently play Ranked. The only benefit I would get is getting called *boosted* for having a different opinion, instead of being called too low-ranked to have a valid opinion. Neither of which are or would be true, but it doesn't stop the gobshites who continually vomit this garbage.

I will cede that a diamond player has more mechanical skill at the game, definitely. Or, at the very least, far more patience, in some players' cases. But you don't get me to respect your opinion by being reddit trash.

its funny how low elo players always get so offended when you call them out on their elo. its like you might even be right, but it doesnt matter anymore because all you do is throw around insults and complaints. i enjoy it.

Lee sins lategame doesnt fall off at all because he has very high base damage, very high scaling combined with %missing health damage, aoe slows and the strongest cc in the game. 

sure he does get outscaled many things by many champions and so his relative effectiveness falls off but his power doesnt. he doesnt suddenly stop scaling (like, for example, elise does because of her lack of an ultimate) and he has many valid build paths to be a high threat while being very tanky. also, the most important point about lee sin is his kick which simply never falls off. if you kick a key target into your team, ofcourse thats very good and it can end a game at any point. but even if you dont kick him into your team but simply away from your team or over a wall, thats allready winning fights.  if lee sin kicks a tank through your team, that also ends fights. he has many options to kick and his ultimate remains game-deciding no matter how long the game goes. even if he builds almost full tank you cant simply ignore him because of how dangerous his kick is. 

if you build more damage on him, his assassination potential on squishies doesnt fall off either because of how insanely high his scaling numbers are.  the only thing that falls off is his dueling potential but since he can always kick you, he cant be killed in a duel either.
and this argument "vs good players this doesnt work" is a silver player saying vs good players HE COULDNT pull it off. in a realistic scenario, good players usually play vs other good players so that equalizes and the only thing that remains is if it is physically possible for lee sin to reach a target and kick it. andyes, it is absolutely physically possible to do it from the design of his kit and to prevent it, resources must be used on him either to cc him or to kill him. this means he is infact a threat and even tho the threat is not purely damage, it sometimes is much greater a threat than damage.

that said, lee sin doesnt fall off.

compare him to elise: her damage falls off because she has no ultimate and her mid to lategame damage is not burst but DPS which, if she builds squishy, has no way of dealing while if she builds tanky, is simply too low. elises mid to lategame is still impactfull but can not be compared to her earlygame or other champions mid to lategame. thats why it can be said that she doesnt only fall off compared to other champions but also compared to her own power of impact during the game.
this does not apply to lee sin, thus it can be said he doesnt fall off.

lee sins main power is not that his physical constitution is extremely strong. his main power is that he has immense pressure due to the combination of mobility, utility and damage. this pressure stays the same all game long or against some teamcomps, even rises.



PS: about the rank thing - it is theoretically possible to know things about the game as a low elo player that a higher elo player doesnt know, especially if the higher elo player is a yasuo main, but generally speaking, league of legends doesnt use mechanical skills. its 99% knowledge and experience and only 1% mechanics. faker doesnt actually have insane mechanics (they are super high class elite, thats for sure, but he isnt the only one or better than every other pro at this), but he simply knows his shit much better. he simply knows the damage he can deal and take very well and  he knows the in-fight options of players very well.
its knowledge and experience that makes good players seem good, not their ability to press 3 buttons in fast succession. everyone can do that.

in league, a general concept is "if you know it, you can do it" but knowing needs alot of experience. for example, i played alot of warcraft 3 tft and i was very good at it. in warcraft, you needed alot more mechanics than in league and also alot more strategic knowledge but since the game was so much more complex and involved many more units and factors than league, you didnt have to know the specifics to be a good player.

this means, you could actually have a session with a player where you teach him everything you know in theory and then let him play and he will be able to apply a certain amount of things you taught him just from telling him. in league tho, it is possible to only teach very basic concepts in theory alone and most things must be learned from practicing because of how much more this game relies on experience. you either know from experience that you can win this duel with 20 hp left or you dont know it. no matter how many lessons you learned, you will not do the math before dueling so you simply have to experience it plus you gotta have a good feeling for it.

this leads to the conclusion that purely theoretical experience, even though valuable in some areas, is very unreliable in league of legends in general. especially when talking about champion power and balance. 
a player with many more games than another player generally should have more experience, regardless of rank. but a player who played, say, 1000 games in diamond is inclined to know more about the same thing than a player who played 1000 games in silver. this is due to the circumstances in which either player made their experiences.
the diamond player simply had a much harsher environment in which mistakes are punished more precisely and more commonly. this means, higher level experience is closer to facts than lower level experience.

for example: champ X against champ Y matchup in toplane. who wins? you say champ X because mobafire said so. i say champ Y because i main champ Y and i played 300 games against champ X and i know the limits of champ X because i played against people who were able to use champ X to its limit.
even if you played the same amount of games in this matchup, chances are your opponents didnt use as much power of champ X as my opponents and you didnt use as much power of champ Y as me because if you did, you'd be in diamond too.

does that make sense to you? if a challenger player, who is CURRENTLY CHALLENGER (not these people who had 5 accounts in top 10 challenger but are now plat 2) comes to me and explains me some things about jungling, i will surely listen and be thankful to get the chance to improve myself. even tho they are not neccessarily better at everything, they will have with 100% certainy at least one area of knowledge where they surpass me and i can learn from it.


i just feel like writing more, so another example i got for you: my manager is gold something and he knows alot about the game for a gold player, i must say.  he always complains about how stupid his allies are and how he knows everything better and he should play with diamonds too. in fact, he very much belongs in gold and not in diamond. he knows many things that other golds dont but he also lacks alot of knowledge a plat potentially has. he lacks experience and definitely awareness.
also, an interesting concept about knowledge is that one information alone can be worthless and its value only shows when combining it with other information.
lets say you got information A, B and C and you feel like you know alot. now sadly, all those informations dont do shit for you unless you got information Q aswell.
since most scenarios in league consist of many many MANY variables, generalizing scenarios is very hard and you either need ALOT of practice experience or you need to understand which fundamental basics have the most value and in exactly this last point, lower level players tend to understand much less (or they wouldnt be lower level). 
this is just tendencies, so you could be the most knowledgeable player in the world even tho you are silver. chances are pretty slim tho and if you want someone who is higher level to respect your knowledge, you gotta actually drop knowledge and back it up.

i know its hard and i have probably never seen a lower elo player drop respectable knowledge except once some diamond midlaner was able to completely own and destroy every challenger midlaner and explain to them how midlane works and they were like "eh wtf new world order" but that aside, silvers fail to impress.

I thought that was common language on the boards, but I guess having to point out the exact meaning of the phrase in that context is a simpler misunderstanding to correct, especially since you already said it yourself.

The post was getting too long. Anyway, regarding "my Gold boss," the concept of every piece of information being crucial to success, scenarios having too many variables to be over-generalized...

I have not *once* said anything about "deserving" a higher rank. All I've stated is that I haven't been playing the game for rank, and that is why the ranking I have is low.

Yes, information is all-important, and all of the information is important. As dumb as that sentence may sound, it's the core truth of this game, and even life itself. You can't go into a situation without knowing what's going on and expect to come out on top of things.

Yes, scenarios can have many variables that change the whole dynamic of the situation. They took Cleanse instead of Ignite. They invaded the jungle instead of starting on their side. They swapped mid- and top-lane, changing the match-up entirely. It can even come down to something as small as a specific champ walking at a different angle than you expected. **This means that a scenario theory needs to be vague, in order to handle multiple contingencies.** And it obviously won't be perfect, because the variables present allow for vastly different scenarios.

ill try to keep it shorter this time:
1. "falls off lategame" means "is less useful lategame than before that", which simply doesnt apply to lee sin. "falls off" is a term used when talking about curves and as long as his power curve does not go down with time passing in the game, i dont understand where you can imply that it falls off. 

2. from what i see, people use the term "falls off lategame" equivalent to "does not scale as good". as i said, elise falls off lategame because her impact is lower in the lategame than in the earlygame while lee sin always stays the same (or even increases) due to his kick. this is what i understand when i say "falls off".

3. i dont mean to "teach" you anything. its more like this is a forum and we just post whatever we think about a certain topic and if someone saith something that we deem wrong or right or augmentable, we give our opinion. 
i dont mean to teach you personally, else i'd offer you coaching and let myself get paid for it, but simply give a diamond players insight on the game.

4. from my own experience i can say, rank matters alot when it comes to game knowledge. if you dont think so, you can simply value this argument lower. for example, when i say "champ X is pretty weak" and someone saith "but palyer Y is high challenger with it so it cant be that weak" then that definitely is evidence but i value it so low that i can leave it out of any calculation. if you value rank-evidence low, you can just do that for yourself and let others value it high.

that being said, im not talking at you for being low/unranked, im just reminding everyone that everything you say is from a certain perspective and everything i say is from another perspective not only influenced by us being different people but also by our ranks. 
again, if you think that argument has no value, simply dont consider it. what im saying is not based on my rank and i dont use my rank as an argument, i simply back it up with my rank. from my own opinion, this backup is relatively strong but if it isnt from yours, thats fine too.

Using that definition, there literally is no champion that "falls off" late-game, because there is no champion that gets *worse* late-game than early-game.

When a champion's power falls off late-game, it doesn't mean their power curve goes on a decline; it means that it doesn't keep going up as fast. An example would be Yasuo, whose damage output spikes up quickly between 5-30 minutes, but slows down after that point both in relation to his own power scaling and in relation to other melee carries. His power isn't going *down,* but it's not going up as fast as it was earlier.
> 2) from what i see, people use the term "falls off lategame" equivalent to "does not scale as good". as i said, elise falls off lategame because her impact is lower in the lategame than in the earlygame while lee sin always stays the same (or even increases) due to his kick. this is what i understand when i say "falls off".

The funny thing is that Lee Sin has a similar situation to Elise. Not nearly as pronounced, thanks to his ultimate, but his kit pretty heavily relies on being able to deal DPS. However, he can't buy enough of both damage *and* defense in order to keep up his DPS in the middle of a fight, and his only defensive tool is his W, which is *far* more often used to engage/escape than purely for defense.

You can keep disregarding that opinion, but I want you to consider something very important. **When does Lee Sin become popular?**

Think about this for a moment. Lee Sin only jumps to the top of popularity when the average match is less than 35 minutes. It's also interesting to note that the average gold gained in a 30-minute match is 11k, which is enough to buy 2-3 completed items, depending on how much you invest in boots. *So when the end-game is during his mid-game, Lee Sin becomes much more popular. Why is that?*

In the years that I've been around this game, I've seen pretty much every possible combination of rank and player intelligence. Only thing I haven't seen is Master rank players on the forums, and they're either too busy smurfing for fun or playing high-level matches to bother with the forums. 

This leads me to one truth: you cannot base someone's understanding of the game on rank. Their rank will, at best, accurately note their experience and **ability to apply** game knowledge, as well as their teamwork skills beyond Silver.

Rank does not usually matter in a discussion. What matters is the player knowing the subject well enough to base their opinions/arguments on facts, and being able to trade debate points. If someone is high rank *and* knowledgeable on the subject, it definitely solidifies my respect for their opinions, but it's not a requirement for me to consider it valid.

Also, when it conflicts what other players of similar rank have said, I tend to see it as one man's opinion against the rest. They could be right, but more players are saying they're wrong for reasons X, Y and Zed, and none of their counter-points are dispelling the facts laid out.

In any event, the discussion subject would be more important than the ranking of those in the discussion, *but it's true that your extensive experience would lend your words far more weight than the average player.* Again, I regard individual intelligence over the game's mechanical approximation of a player's skill, but this is a case where, logically and statistically, that information actually grants leverage.

Ranking may not be necessary to validate game knowledge, but it verifies experience. Chances are that I'd probably agree with you on the Pantheon discussion. Main reason why we're even disagreeing on Lee Sin is because what you say is going against so many other facts and opinions.

well, we are kinda agreeing on many things here.

tho if i recall correctly, it was mainly about lee sin and the term "falls off", right?

so you are saying  no champion "falls off" from how i understand that phrase because no champion loses power? well not exactly. no champion becomes a weaker version of himself but  many champions lose impact over the course of the game. the best example really is elise because not only drops the power-growth of her kit so drastically past 6 that her impact simply FALLS OFF but her abilities are also designed in a way that it is very hard to itemize to properly use them past, i say, the jungle item.

also, every single one of her abilities is designed to be low-impact and only the combination makes her strong. this means, later on in the game she has no abilitiy to singlehandedly impact a fight except her stun which can only reliably used to peel. her impact on the fights/game is very low right now.

lee sin ofcourse suffers from the same things and you are absolutely right about his abilities and his buildpath BUT the ultimate becomes more and more impactful the longer the game goes (respawn timers, health items on frontliners etc) and keeps his power curve stable. he doesnt fall off as his impact doesnt decrease. he simply stays as impactful as ever or even grows slightly.

there are many champions who fall off lategame but its true, with the short gametimes we have right now that applies to less champions than before.


also the second thing you say is that lee sin is popular with short gametimes. that is correlating for sure but i felt like its much more the other way around. when season 6 came around i tested almost all junglers extensively (because im a jungler, makes sense) and i found that three champions in particular have a very sick early power and, due to the new season, are way more impactful than before. these three are lee sin, kindred and rexai.

the new jungle does a few things for junglers.
1. it gives more experience the more you fall behind, so the less you farm, the faster you catch up which basically frees up time you can "fuck around" and still get back, which benefits junglers who like to spend their time ganking and fucking around.

2. it gives less gold so the junglers looking to farm up in the jungle dont benefit from that as much anymore and junglers who reliably get their gold outside of the jungle just have way less downsides from not farming as much.

3. jungle items are more expensive and give a different form of sustain which guts all champions having a hard time in jungle anyways. now its mostly due to having much less mana sustain and no masteries (except the neglible 5 on hit dmg) that actually help jungling. this means all junglers who naturally jungle and sustain nicely get buffed indirectly even more

4. yeah there is a fourth point even. so many buffs for these junglers. from the new masteries, fighting in lanes and trading has been buffed and is encouraged MUCH more than last season, so laners fight and trade way more frequently which makes ganking much easier and increases the success rate of ganks drastically so champions who have strong early ganks and can gank frequently due to no/low resource cost/cooldowns have an advantage here too.

That doesn't mean League requires no mechanics to play. It means it requires *less* mechanics.
